Work Program for Reviewing and Improving: 'speaker_1': 'Thank you. Please read the next agenda item.'

'speaker_2': 'A Jeanette M to resolution 31808 relating to the for high transportation industry, establishing a work program for the City Council to review the administrative rules and regulations to improve customer service and lower cost to participants and to explore ways to ensure equal market access to all participants.'
'speaker_2': 'The committee recommends a resolution be adopted as amended.'

'speaker_1': 'Thank you very much. So, first of all, I want to thank everyone for coming out, taking time out of their busy day to testify on the resolution. And even though some of the policy points in this resolution may be inconsistent with what you want or what you believe is right.'

'speaker_1': 'I appreciate everyone coming out and taking playing a role in the process. And having said that, I like the few expressions that I heard in this resolution, which is basically a resolution to this establishing a work program to address a number of issues, not just race, but a number of issues in this industry.'

'speaker_1': 'The expression, as I like, were debunking the myths, and I think someone said that the Teamsters brought this resolution. It was actually drafted by center staff here, working collectively with all industry participants.'

'speaker_1': 'Representatives, yes. Labor groups, drivers and and writers. And having said that, what we're trying to do is, yes, we are trying to ensure a level playing field, equal market access for all industry participants. And I would remind folks that are really fascinated with the new technology, the new platforms that have been invented, that there are people who'

'speaker_1': 'have worked for decades in this industry keeping our mobile transportation alive. And I don't think it's consistent with our policies to simply not consider the legacy participants in addressing issues of fairness in moving forward. So it's not a question of flattening all tires.'

'speaker_1': 'It's a question of looking at our core values in an industry that continues to evolve and trying to get the data that we need to make smart decisions. And that is what this this resolution is attempting to do.'

'speaker_1': 'Most importantly as well, it make sure that we have a safe and reliable ride experience for consumers and cost effective. We are aligned. We align ourselves in all of our legislation with issues of equity and fair compensation and transparency.'

'speaker_1': 'And while we applaud. Uber or Lyft or TNC folks for getting so many people down here to testify. 'speaker_1': 'cab charging race that we, in my opinion, heavily, heavily regulate. And I think we are trying to go to a playing field where we will see more of a policy, a less of a regulatory feel and more of a free market feel, but making sure that issues of fairness to every participant is first and foremost.'

'speaker_1': 'So what does this resolution do to debunk the myth? First of all, it will establish a minimum rate. We are not raising the rates for it for consumers out there. That is a myth. 'speaker_1': 'mile. It may be to 30 or 150. That is why we are trying to establish the data. And the 240 was not pulled out of a hat. It was looking at what the rate per mile was back in 2014.'

'speaker_1': 'That rate is now at 135. 'speaker_6': 'Okay. Thank you. PRESENTER Terrell, this resolution, as was mentioned, does not implement any new policy or law. It lays out simply lays out a workplan for future discussions about the conditions imposed on drivers by giant companies like Uber.'

'speaker_6': 'I will be voting yes on it, but I also would like to make some general points about worker organizing in 2018 because I think that's very relevant to what we're talking about here. Uber is a $15 billion multinational corporation that uses its money and power to skirt labor law and to avoid having to pay drivers living wages'

'speaker_6': 'or basic benefits. They have attempted to deny drivers the right to democratically organize and form a union by calling drivers independent contractors rather than workers. As we all know, the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals will soon rule on the Seattle D.A. driver collective bargaining ordinance.'

'speaker_6': 'The court does the right thing and restores the right to democratically organize to D.A. workers. Then unionizing should be the first thing on the movement work plan. If not, I think we need to take the lessons from the inspiring strike of West Virginia teachers only a month ago.'

'speaker_6': 'West Virginia is one of those states which has the anti-union legislation with the misleading name of Right to Work, which I think really should be called Right to work for less. Teachers in West Virginia could not legally organize a close shop union.'

'speaker_6': 'They could not legally bargain their contract collectively, and they could not legally go on strike. But as Dr. Martin Luther King Jr, whose 50th anniversary of assassination just occurred, said one has a moral responsibility to disobey unjust laws.'

'speaker_6': 'And that is exactly what the West Virginia teachers did. They organized a united strike, shutting down every school in all 55 counties of the state and brought all those striking workers to the state capitol to protest the legislature and the governor.'
'speaker_6': 'And keep in mind.'
'speaker_1': 'No interruptions, please. No interruptions. That would be disruptive. Thank you very much, ma'am.'

'speaker_6': 'And this nine day wildcat strike was enormously successful because the teachers knew that without their work, the schools could not open. I think these are general lessons that have been taken seriously, not only by teachers in other states like Oklahoma and'

'speaker_6': 'Kentucky to strike for school funding, but their influence is starting to spread. And I think the whole labor movement and workers as a whole, all of us, workers as a whole, should be taking lessons from what teachers have achieved in West Virginia because they have showed the world that workers have immense power.'

'speaker_6': 'When we get organized, whether we are drivers, a bus drivers, taxi drivers, teachers, custodial workers, no matter what work we do. And if workers do that, I will, of course, as a working person and as a rank and file member of the labor movement myself, I will stand with you.'

'speaker_6': 'I do have one message, a friendly message of solidarity to the drivers who have come here under the label of drive forward. I hope you will take that into consideration. I don't think you will agree with me right now, but I would like to convey that friendly message to you.'

This is a really great opportunity and I think we're leading by example not only with creating a green energy economy, but'

'speaker_2': 'making sure more people have access to these good living wage jobs. We know that historically the folks who are most affected by climate change are those who've done the least to cause it, especially low wage workers, women and people of color who often live on the margins and are more likely to suffer the consequences of climate change'
'speaker_2': '. So what we're doing today, I think, is really forward looking, very inclusive, and I'm excited to work with our council on this.'
'speaker_1': 'Thank you, Councilmember Mosquito. So, Councilmember Skinner, would you like to make a formal motion to amend Section five?'
'speaker_2': 'I move that we amend Section five with the proposed legislation that is in front of you.'
'speaker_7': 'Okay.'

'speaker_1': 'To move moving second to amend section five as stated by councilmember skater. All those in favor of the amendment please vote i. I opposed the have a minute piece of legislation. Councilmember Skate, did you have any further words on this legislation?'

'speaker_2': 'Well, Mr. President, I apologize for not asking you about this beforehand, but I wondered if we might suspend the rules to see if Dennis has any comments that you'd like to add before we vote on this as well.'
'speaker_1': 'If there's no objection, we could hear from Mr. Hayes for a few moments to grace us with a few words of wisdom on this legislation.'
'speaker_2': 'Thank you for letting me put you on the spot, Mr. Hayes.'
'speaker_1': 'No problem. But the 22nd clock on him, please.'
'speaker_4': 'Yeah.'

'speaker_0': 'Thank you, Mr. Chairman. Members of the Council. I think that all of the most important things have already been said by Councilmember Mosquito. The one addition that I would make as someone who's been in this field now for well in excess of four decades, almost always when you're dealing with something that enhances the greenness or the efficiency'

'speaker_0': 'of buildings, it's a zero sum game. Somebody pays, somebody receives, somebody wins. Somebody loses. This particular energy efficiency as a service approach, which we used to refer to as Meets and Cantlie, this is a better name for it is one where everybody wins.'

'speaker_0': 'The tenants get a much better building. The landlord gets a reasonable return on its investment. The utility continues to make a rate of return. And all of the other utility ratepayers who would have to pay something if we were not to get new energy supplies instead of investing in efficiencies, keep their rates low.'

'speaker_0': 'And of course, there are those very high quality jobs that come out of it as well. It's win, win, win across the board. And I'm delighted that the council seemed favorably disposed toward it.'
'speaker_1': 'Thank you, sir. Okay. Well, I think that's a good segue into a vote. Please call the roll on the passage of the bill.'
'speaker_3': 'Gonzales, i. Herbold, i. Johnson Mosquera i. O'Brien Sergeant. President. Harrell All right. Seven in favor and unopposed.'
'speaker_1': 'The bill passes and the chair will sign it. All right, please read agenda item number 15.'
